bibl.title: Letter from S.C. Mead to A.S. von Mansfelde, November 20, 1907

div1.p: Mead, on behalf of the Merchants' Association of New York, expresses support for the Carroll and Lazear pension bills.

div1.head: Letter from S.C. Mead to A.S. von Mansfelde, November 20, 1907
div1.opener:
h
November 20, 1907
Dr. A. S. v. Mansfelde, Treasurer,
Nebraska State Medical Association,
Ashland, Nebr.
My dear Sir:
div1.p:
Your letter of recent date, which outlines the plans you
propose for the increased pension of Mrs. Mabel H. Lazear, is very
welcome.

We are in accord with your view that Congress should also
grant a proper pension to the widow of Major Carroll.

This Association is perfectly agreeable to the introduc-
ing of the two Special Acts in the House of Representatives by
your Congressman, Hon. Edmund H. Hinshaw, and in the Senate by Hon.
Philander C. Knox and Hon. Charles Dick, our sole desire being to
put the legislation in such hands as to make certain its early en-
actment. It will be our pleasure and privilege to support these
measures.

We are also of the opinion that the Special Act which
gave Mrs. Walter Reed a pension should be used for the two widows
and their children. The only question in our mind is as to the
amount of the pension. In his “Memorandum For the President”,
dated Aug. 30, 1906, Brigadier-General R. M. O'Reilly, Surgeon-
General, U. S. Army, referring to Dr. Jesse W. Lazear, says:-

“His widow's pension should be increased
to $100. a month x x x”

In view of this specific recommendation from the Medical
Division of the War Department, it might be well to consider whether
the pension specified in the Bill should not be in accord therewith.

We note your statement that in all probability the
National Legislative Council of the American Medical Association at
its forthcoming meeting will vote to stand sponsor for the Bills in
question. It will be of material assistance if the various county
medical societies, at the instance of the American Medical Associa-
tion, adopt resolutions calling on the respective Congressmen to
support and work for the passage of the legislation presented at the
request of your organization and this Association.

On Dec. 5, 1906, at the time the pension for Mrs. Reed
was pending, President Roosevelt transmitted the following message
to Congress:

“The inclosed papers are transmitted to the
Congress in the earnest hope that it will take suitable
action in the matter. Major Reed's part in the experi-
ments which resulted in teaching us how to cope with yel-
low fever was such as to render mankind his debtor, and
this nation should in some proper fashion bear witness
to this fact.”

The “papers” represented the “Memorandum for the Presi-
dent”, prepared by Surgeon-General O'Reilly, referred to above.
In view of the President's interest, thus shown, it is our inten-
tion to request that he transmit another Message to Congress speci-
fically calling attention to the services rendered by Dr. Lazear
and Major Carroll. From the conversation the writer had with
Surgeon-General O'Reilly and Major Ireland we feel that their act-
ive co-operation and valuable assistance can be counted upon.

Immediately after the Bills have been introduced we shall
communicate with The Merchants' Association of San Francisco, with
Dr. A. S. v. Mansfelde,
- 3 -
which our relations are very friendly, and with the New Orleans
Board of Trade, suggesting the adoption of resolutions urging the
California and Louisiana delegation in Congress to vote for the
increased pensions.

All the people of the Pacific Coast and those of the
Gulf Coast, as much so as those living along the Atlantic seaboard,
and the mercantile community in particular, owe an everlasting
debt of gratitude to the members of the Commission which conducted
in Cuba the mosquito experiments.

The saving to trade and commerce alone by the control of
yellow fever is incalculable. We feel, certain, therefore, that
the commercial organizations of the sections named will be eager
to do all in their power to induce the Federal Government to provide
for the proper support of the families of Dr. Lazear and Major
Carroll.

We enclose herein, as requested, copies of the draft of
bill which you sent us. We think it important for Congressman
Hinshaw to be prepared to introduce the measures as soon as Congress
convenes. We also suggest that both he and you at once get in
touch with Senators Knox and Dick, keeping us posted as to the
progress made.

Awaiting with interest full advice as to the action taken
at the meeting of the National Legislative Council on the 10 prox.,
we remain, with assurances that you may feel at liberty to convey
to your organization our willingness to co-operate to the fullest
possible extent in the desire that the National Government fittingly
express the sentiments of the people as to the noble sacrifice, in
Dr. A. S. v. Mansfelde,
- 4 -
the service of their country and in the interest of science, made
by Dr. Jesse W. Lazear and Major James Carroll.
div1.closer:
Yours very truly, THE MERCHANTS' ASSOCIATION OF NEW YORK,
By ...(Signed)...S. C. Mead
Secretary, ENCL:
DRAFT OF BILL.
